title: Which individual owns the largest amount of U.S. land? - Quora

response.answer_text: The federal government owns the most land, nearly 30% of all the land in the country. State governments also own quite a bit. Outside of Alaska, which contains large swaths of state-owned land, almost 40 percent of state land in the United States is found in the East. Some eastern states own vast amounts of land, such as New Jersey (21 percent of the state); Florida (16 percent); New York (14 percent), Pennsylvania (14 percent), Michigan (13 percent), and Minnesota (11%) As to individuals who own the most land: John Malone owns 2.2 million acres of land. Ted Turner owns two million acres across seven states. The Emmerson family own 1.9 million acres of land. Brad Kelly owns 1.7 million acres of land The Reed Family owns 1.3 million acres of land. The Irving Family owns 1.2 million acres of land. The Singleton Family owns 1.1 million acres if land. The King Family owns 900,000 acre pops of land. Stan Kroenke owns more than 865,000 acres of land The Pingree Family owns 830,000 acres of land

Who owns the most non-federally owned land in the United States of America? The Navajo Nation of course. The land they control and own is located in Arizona, Colorado, New Mexico and Utah. The Tribal Nation is one of three such nations in the united states to control more than 10,000 square miles of land. See, the whole secret to large Indian Reservations, as they are called in the US, is that the natives didn’t start a war with the Americans. The Utes, the Navajo, and the Hopi just wanted to be left alone. The Navajo had migrated south to Arizona following about 30 years of harsh winters and famine. They traveled until they found a place with no other people. and could grow their crops and livestock in peace. For eight hundred years they have continually lived in the same place. In fact. they are likely the longest-surviving unaltered tribe in North America. Now, interestingly enough, since before World War 2, the Navajo have considered themselves Americans, as well as natives. Many of them have served in the US military, many have successful business empires. and others are well educated at many universities. The most common way to meet a Navajo outside of the reservation is in court. There are many Navajo lawyers. In some ways they inspire me, as they are the prime example as to how the rest of the human race should act. They just want to live in peace… More to consider…
